Recipe.title: Salsa
Recipe.Description:
After experimenting with a few batches, we found making salsa was a lot of messy work, so we decided we needed a recipe we could can. That way we could make one big mess, but then enjoy salsa whenever we wanted it.
So we read all about canning salsa. One thing we learned was that if the salsa is not acidic enough, then it spoils easily. Unfortunately, many of today's hybrid tomatoes are intentionally low in acid. To avoid problems, most recipes dump large amounts of lemon-juice or vinegar into the recipes which ends up making the recipe taste terrible. We did find one recipe that didn't seem to be over-doing it and based our recipe on it.
It tasted wonderful!
But we had one self-prolclaimed "expert" tell us there was no way it would pass FDA regulations for safety. By a fortunate coincidence, one of our neighbors worked at a cannery and had equipment to perform testing for FDA regulations. We tested our recipe and it passed!
Caution: Follow the recipe exactly! Do not substitute (except as noted below)! Especially with the tomatoes!

section.instruction: Core the tomatoes by cutting out the white portion inside the tomato where the stem was attached.

Peel the tomatoes by cutting an X just through the skin on the bottom of the tomato.
Dip the tomato in a pot of boiling water for a few seconds until the skin begins to peel back around the X, then immediately remove the tomato and put it in ice water.
The tomato should now just slip out of its skin.
Chop tomatoes into chunks about the size of the end of your thumb, from the last knuckle to the tip.
Chop peppers and onions into pieces about ¼-inch square.
Make sure the lime juice is bottled (not fresh) and real (not imitation).
Use fresh Cilantro. Remove the leaves and discard the stems. Finely chop the leaves and press into cup when measuring.
When all of the ingredients are prepared, put them into a pot and bring to a full boil for 5 minutes.
Immediately fill hot pint jars leaving ½-1 inch at the top of the jar, then put on the lids.
Follow instructions in the Bath Canning: How-To section.

Notes.note:
Cooking time in Bath Canner:
Altitude Time
Below 1000 feet 15 minutes
1000-6000 feet 20 minutes
Above 6000 feet 25 minutes

Modifications.modification: It is very important to follow the recipe exactly. The items that can be adjusted are listed below. This is CRITICAL to keep the salsa from spoiling.
You may adjust the amount of Cilantro, Garlic, Salt or Black Pepper to taste.
You may reduce the amount of Peppers or Onions, but do not increase.
You may substitute 1 cup of the Anaheim peppers with 1 cup of Jalapeño peppers, for a spicier salsa.
You may substitute some or all of the bottled real lime juice with bottled real lemon juice. (This is usually less expensive, but in my opinion, tastes nowhere near as good.)
